Wherefore Ambrose appears to me to have very beautifully exemplified this righteousness in the benediction of Jacob3 that as he, who had on his own account no claim to the privileges of primogenitura, being concealed in his brother’s habit, and invested with his garment, which dif- fuseda most excellent odour, insinuated himself into the favour of his father, that he might receive the benediction to his own advantage, under the character of another, so we shelter our· selves under the precious purity of Christ our elder brother, that we may obtain the testimony of righteousness in the sight of God. The words of Ambrose are, “That Isaac smelled the odour of the garments, perhaps indicates, that we are justified not by works, but by faith; since the infimrity of the flesh is an impediment to works, bnt the brightness of saith, which merite the pardon of sin, conceals the error of our actions.''
